titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize Ms. Codex 708: Sancti Augustini opera quaedam :

notesStmt.note: Title from caption title (f. 1r), added in a later hand.

Incipit and explicit for item 14: Incipit epistola Johannis Papae urbis Romae de fide contra Euticianistas de duobus naturis in una persona Domini Nostri Iesu Christi. Dominis filiis merito illustribus atque...filii merito illustres atque magnifici.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Comprises works by Augustine; works erroneously attributed to Augustine, including a translation from Aristotle; and works by other authors including Ambrose, Possidius, Orosius, and a letter of Pope John II.
msContents.textLang: Latin, with some lines of Greek

author.persName: Ambrose, Saint, Bishop of Milan, d. 397

msItem.title: De laude et exhortatione viduitatis, f. 23r
Retractatio in libro ad horosium contra priscillianistas, f. 36r
Commonitorium ad sanctum Augustinum de priscillianistis et origenis errore, f. 36r
Responsio ad orosium de priscillianistis et origenis errore, f. 37v
Retractatio in libro de correctione donatistarum, f. 43r
Retractatio in libro de fide et operibus, f. 58r
Cathegorie translate a beato Augustino de greco in latinum, f. 87r
Commonitorium ad universam ecclesiam destinatum sub qua cautela manichei si conversi fuerint suscipi debeant , f. 102v
Epistola de fide contra Euticianistas de duobus naturis in una persona domini nostri Iesu Christi, f. 104r

supportDesc.extent: 112 leaves : 266 x 181 (191 x 118) mm. bound to 277 x 191 mm

collation.p: Parchment, ii (modern paper) + 112 + ii (modern paper); 1⁷(+1 in position 4), 2⁸(single leaves in positions 2 and 7), 3-4⁸, 5⁴, 6-9⁸, 10¹¹(+1 in position 10), 11⁸, 12¹⁰, 13-14⁸; [1-112]; modern foliation in ink, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 32-33 long lines; ruled in lead; prickings visible.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in an early Gothic script by 4 different hands.

origin.p: Written in Pontigny, France, mid-12th century (Helen Zakin).

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Sir Thomas Phillipps, ms. 11901 (note, f. 1r).
